post_message:
"For Muslims in Pakistan, drinking alcohol is prohibited and talking about it is taboo. Drinking and denying it is the oldest cocktail in the country."

Read on in The New York Times Opinion Section.
post_description: Consuming alcohol and denying it is the oldest cocktail in the country.

post_name: Trump’s Win Gives Stocks in Private Prison Companies a Reprieve
post_message: The biggest prison company in the U.S. saw its stock soar 43% the day after Donald J. Trump's victory.
post_description: In the market rally after Donald J. Trump was elected president, two big beneficiaries were operators of prisons and immigration detention centers.

post_name: Both Feeling Threatened, American Muslims and Jews Join Hands
post_message: Donald J. Trump's election victory has unleashed a flood of Islamophobia and anti-Semitism, but also led to a surprising new alliance.
post_description: The two groups are putting aside divisions to combat a wave of Islamophobia and anti-Semitism since Donald J. Trump’s election, and to resist whatever may come next.

post_name: Mexican Report Says Investigators Botched Search for 43 Students
post_message: The Mexican government has refused to release an internal review that found investigators broke the law in their search for 43 missing students.
post_description: A review that the government refuses to release found that suspects had been arrested and moved illegally, jeopardizing any criminal case in the 2014 disappearance.

post_name: Justice Dept. Sues Michigan City After Mosque Plan Is Rejected
post_message: “We have definitely seen a spike in these cases, in problems when it comes to minority religions,” Azzam Elder, the lead lawyer for the community center, said. “It is a sign of the times.”
post_description: The lawsuit said the City of Sterling Heights discriminated against a Muslim group and noted that residents spoke in opposition to the mosque in public meetings.

post_name: In Indonesia, an Islamic Edict Seeks to Keep Santa Hats Off Muslims
post_message: Indonesia's largest body of Islamic clerics issued a religious edict barring Muslims from wearing Christmas-themed clothing.
post_description: Many Indonesians think the edict may be politically and racially motivated.

post_name: The Enemy Within: Bribes Bore a Hole in the U.S. Border
post_message: Over the last decade, nearly 200 Department of Homeland Security workers accepted bribes to let immigrants and drugs into the country, a New York Times review found.
post_description: Homeland Security employees have looked the other way as tons of drugs and thousands of undocumented immigrants were smuggled into the U.S., a New York…

post_name: Faster Growth? Two Things Trump Supporters Won’t Like
post_message: The 2 strategies that would most directly help achieve economic growth are things that clash with other planks of Donald J. Trump's agenda.
post_description: Productivity through automation and economic dynamism through immigration could hurt blue-collar workers.

post_name: De Blasio and Big City Mayors Try Pooling Their Power Against Trump
post_message: NYC Mayor Bill de Blasio is rallying mayors around the U.S. to help defend immigrants and minorities during Donald J. Trump's presidency.
post_description: New York’s mayor, casting himself as a defender of immigrants, minorities and others, is among those rallying urban leaders.

post_name: Ford, Criticized by Trump, Cancels Plans to Build Mexican Plant
post_message: Ford Motor Company said it was canceling plans to build a $1.6 billion plant in Mexico and would instead invest $700 million to increase production in Michigan.
post_description: The company said on Tuesday that it would instead invest $700 million to increase production in Michigan.

post_name: Mexicans Are the NAFTA Winners? It’s News to Them
post_message: There's an increasing belief in Mexico that NAFTA has been a big disappointment.
post_description: Donald J. Trump likes to say the trade pact has helped Mexico at the expense of American workers. But for many Mexicans, life is the same struggle as ever.

post_name: What to Watch: Jeff Sessions’s Confirmation Hearing
post_message: Look for Democrats to try to use Jeff Sessions to frame the legal limits of a Donald J. Trump presidency.
post_description: Democrats can’t force Mr. Trump to testify under oath about whether he was serious about wanting to ban Muslim immigrants. But they can ask Mr. Sessions.

post_name: Swiss Muslim Girls Must Attend Swim Classes With Boys, Court Says
post_message: Ensuring the girls’ “successful social integration” took precedence over religious concerns, the court noted.
post_description: The girls’ parents had resisted the mandatory classes on religious grounds, taking their case to the European Court of Human Rights.

post_name: Sessions Says Law ‘Absolutely’ Prohibits Waterboarding
post_message: Breaking News: The attorney general nominee Jeff Sessions said that waterboarding is illegal and that he opposes banning Muslims from the U.S.
post_description: Mr. Sessions offered assurances that he will be an independent attorney general and a check on President-elect Donald J. Trump.

post_name: Transgender Women Fear Abuse in Immigration Detention
post_message: How to protect transgender women in immigration detention has confounded federal authorities.
post_description: Lawyers and advocates say mistreatment and abuse endure, despite guidelines issued by Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

post_name: I Know How It Feels to Be Someone’s ‘Token.’ I’m Sure Ben Carson Does, Too.
post_message: "Tokenism is, above all, a form of misdirection. It’s the smiling Muslim kid on the school brochure, the black editorial assistant in the all-white newsroom, the telegenic woman serving as a campaign spokeswoman."
post_description: Cultivating real diversity can be hard. America’s institutions often turn to an easier tactic: faking it.

post_name: A Love Lost, and a Life to Be Regained
post_message: She takes comfort in walks with her and her late husband's dog. “He’s the only family I have right now,” she said. “He looks at me and understands my heart.”
post_description: Alena Kastsiuk, an immigrant from Belarus, is struggling after the death of her husband.

post_name: Obama, Saying Goodbye, Warns of Threats to National Unity
post_message: "If we decline to invest in the children of immigrants, just because they don’t look like us, we diminish the prospects of our own children — because those brown kids will represent a larger share of America’s work force," President Obama said.
post_description: The president’s confidence was etched with frustration over economic inequity, racism and closed-mindedness that he said imperiled the nation’s democratic fabric.

post_name: Which Martin Luther King Are We Celebrating Today?
post_message:
Martin Luther King "had a message for those who would target immigrants or wall off America from the world. In a 1967 speech, he declared: 'Our loyalties must become ecumenical rather than national.' Instead of policing their borders, nations should 'develop an overriding loyalty to mankind as a whole.'" 
(via The New York Times Opinion Section)
post_description: Since his death, the civil rights leader has been appropriated for all sorts of causes.

post_name: Theresa May Set to Outline U.K. Withdrawal From European Market
post_message: Theresa May's speech holds the potential to define Britain’s relations with its neighbors for decades to come.
post_description: With a long-awaited speech on Tuesday, the British leader is expected to stress regaining control of immigration, even if it means losing trading advantages.

post_name: In ‘Brexit’ Speech, Theresa May Outlines a Clean Break for U.K.
post_message: Breaking News: Theresa May backed a clean break from the EU, its single market and its court system.
post_description: In long-awaited remarks, the British prime minister emphasized regaining control of immigration, even if it means losing trading advantages.

post_name: Cubans Newly Blocked at U.S. Border Place Hopes in Trump
post_message:
Over 1,000 Cuban migrants hoping to reach the U.S. are stranded in Mexico because Barack Obama ended their immigration privileges this month. 

Their hope of entering America now rests in President Donald J. Trump.
post_description: The Obama administration ended special immigration privileges for Cubans after normalizing relations with Cuba. Now migrants arrive into a desperate limbo after an arduous journey.

post_name: The Closing of Trump’s America
post_message: "This is worse than had seemed possible," Roger Cohen writes in the The New York Times Opinion Section.
post_description: A rough translation of “America First” is Muslims last.

post_name: Trump and Mexican President Speak by Phone Amid Dispute Over Wall
post_message:
“We’re going to be working on a fair relationship and a new relationship,” President Donald J. Trump said at a news conference. “I have great respect for the Mexico. I love the Mexican people.”

But “as you know” they have “beaten us to a pulp.”
post_description: The phone call came a day after the two leaders canceled a scheduled meeting after rising tensions over a proposed border wall.

post_name: To Understand a Tax on Mexican Imports, Consider the Avocado
post_message: Enjoy your Super Bowl guacamole. Some of the ingredients might be a little more expensive next year.
post_description: A proposed 20 percent tax could raise the price of heavily imported goods like avocados, while other items produced mainly in the United States could cost less.

post_name: Trump Bars Refugees and Citizens of 7 Muslim Countries
post_message: President Donald J. Trump signed an order suspending the entry of refugees into the U.S. for 120 days, and Syrians indefinitely.
post_description: The president signed an order suspending the entry of refugees into the United States for 120 days, and Syrians indefinitely, and he also ordered preferential treatment for Christians from Muslim nations.

post_name: Trump’s Immigration Ban Is Illegal
post_message: "After a shameful history, Congress outlawed discrimination against immigrants based on national origin in 1965. That means President Donald J. Trump's actions are illegal," writes David Bier, an immigration policy analyst, in The New York Times Opinion Section.
post_description: Congress long ago outlawed discrimination based on national origin.

post_name: Anxiety About Muslim Refugees Is Stoked Online by the Far-Right Media
post_message: Online news outlets often write about refugees resettled in the U.S. with big, scary headlines. The facts tend to be a lot less dramatic.
post_description: Ultraconservative websites like Breitbart and Infowars have published a cycle of eye-popping stories with misleading claims about refugees. And it's beginning to influence public perception, experts say.

post_name: One Certainty of Trump’s Wall: Big Money
post_message: In an almost subversive inversion of the running debate over who will pay for what, the U.S. could ultimately wind up paying Mexican citizens and Mexican-owned businesses to construct the wall.
post_description: An earlier attempt tried cameras and radar but ran over budget. The project was a loss for taxpayers. But for contractors, it was a big win.

post_name: Banned From U.S.: ‘You Need to Go Back to Your Country’
post_message: The Iraqi who once worked for the U.S. military. The Syrian family stranded in a refugee camp. The Iranian medical researcher. All were turned away.
post_description: Refugees and other immigrants from 7 countries, some who were on their way to the U.S. when President Trump signed the order, are no longer able to enter the country.

post_name: Trump’s Immigration Ban Draws Disapproval and Applause
post_message: The reaction to President Donald J. Trump's ban on refugees entering the U.S., with a particular focus on Muslim countries in the Middle East, was swift, certain — and divided.
post_description: Democrats, religious groups, business leaders, academics and others assailed the president’s order as inhumane and discriminatory, while Republicans welcomed it.

post_name: Fears That Trump’s Visa Ban Betrays Friends and Bolsters Enemies
post_message: Across the Muslim world, there was overwhelming agreement that President Donald J. Trump's executive order is a sign that he sees Islam itself as the problem.
post_description: Officials, analysts and citizens across Muslim-majority countries said the order was a sign that President Trump sees Islam itself as the problem.

post_name: Judge Blocks Part of Trump’s Immigration Order
post_message: Breaking News: A federal judge stayed part of President Donald J. Trump's immigration order, barring refugees stopped at U.S. airports from being sent back.
post_description: In a New York courtroom on Saturday evening, the judge said that sending the travelers home could cause them “irreparable harm.”

post_name: In Canada, Justin Trudeau Says Refugees Are Welcome
post_message: "Diversity is our strength." —Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada
post_description: In the wake of President Trump’s order on immigration, the prime minister said his country would accept refugees, “regardless of your faith.”

post_name: Donald Trump’s Muslim Ban Is Cowardly and Dangerous
post_message:
President Donald J. Trump issued the immigration ban on Holocaust Remembrance Day, which speaks of "the president’s callousness and indifference to history, to America’s deepest lessons about its own values." 

Read more in the The New York Times Opinion Section.
post_description: History has its eyes on Trump officials and members of Congress who know better, but are staying silent.

post_name: Protest Grows ‘Out of Nowhere’ at Kennedy Airport After Iraqis Are Detained
post_message: "This is the humanity, this is the soul of America. This is what pushed me to move, leave my country and come here."
post_description: Word of the demonstration filtered out from immigrant-advocacy groups and then got a big push from a prominent voice on social media: Michael Moore.

post_name: In Canada, Justin Trudeau Says Refugees Are Welcome
post_message: "To those fleeing persecution, terror & war, Canadians will welcome you, regardless of your faith," Prime Minister Justin Trudeau wrote on Twitter as President Donald J. Trump's executive order on immigration stranded people around the world.
post_description: In the wake of President Trump’s order on immigration, the prime minister said his country would accept refugees, “regardless of your faith.”

post_name: White House Official, in Reversal, Says Green Card Holders Won’t Be Barred
post_message: Breaking News: After protests, President Donald J. Trump's administration seemed to scale back the president's immigration ban, but confusion continued.
post_description: Reince Priebus, the White House chief of staff, appeared to announce a dramatic change in President Trump’s executive order.

post_name: Fruit of a Poison Tree
post_message: "If Donald J. Trump can impose a Muslim ban until we 'figure out what the hell is going on' with national security threats, we can withhold approval of his Supreme Court nominee until we 'figure out what the hell is going on' with threats to our national elections," Charles M. Blow writes in The New York Times Opinion Section.
post_description: Democrats must oppose Neil Gorsuch on principle.

post_name: Trump Era Invites a Bolder Hollywood Red Carpet
post_message: If there was one consequence President Donald J. Trump probably didn’t foresee from his travel ban, it would be helping a Muslim American secure an award from The Academy.
post_description: Before, people looked askance at serious mentions of policy at movie awards ceremonies. Now, it seems to be expected in winners’ speeches.

post_name: Foreigners Trapped in the United States by New Policy
post_message: President Donald J. Trump's immigration ban imperils the residency status of thousands of immigrants living in the U.S.
post_description: The State Department’s cancellation of the visas of people from seven mainly Muslim nations has thousands of legal residents fearful of leaving lest they be unable to return.

post_name: Uber C.E.O. to Leave Trump Advisory Council After Criticism
post_message: Uber's CEO said he would step down from a Trump advisory council because of the executive order on immigration.
post_description: Travis Kalanick plans to step down from the president’s council, according to an email he sent to employees.

post_name: Yemenis Close Bodegas and Rally to Protest Trump’s Ban
post_message: “This order goes against everything we came here for and everything America stands for,” said Abdul Salam Mubaraz, a bodega owner who had closed his shop.
post_description: About 500 of the shops in New York City shut for much of the day to express disapproval of President Trump’s executive order on immigration.

post_name: Iran to Bar American Wrestling Team From World Cup
post_message: Iran will bar the American wrestling team from a major international meet in response to Donald J. Trump's immigration ban.
post_description: A spokesman for the Iranian Foreign Ministry said the ministry opposed the Americans’ participation because of President Trump’s order on immigration.

post_name: Court Temporarily Blocks Trump’s Travel Ban, and Airlines Are Told to Allow Passengers
post_message: UPDATED: A federal judge in Seattle temporarily blocked President Donald J. Trump's immigration order from being enforced nationwide, reopening America’s door to visa holders from 7 predominantly Muslim countries.
post_description: A judge in Seattle ordered a nationwide halt to the ban while a Boston court refused to extend a stay. Earlier the State Department said 60,000 visas had been revoked.

post_name: A Different Super Bowl Matchup: Politics vs. the N.F.L.
post_message: Politics and football may collide in an uncomfortable way on the country’s biggest sports stage.
post_description: Despite the national tumult over immigration spilling over, Commissioner Roger Goodell said, “I’m singularly focused on the Super Bowl right now.”

post_name: Trump Attacks Judge Who Blocked Visa Ban
post_message: President Donald J. Trump attacked a federal judge who temporarily blocked his immigration order, calling him a "so-called judge" whose "ridiculous" ruling would be overturned.
post_description: In announcing its intent to appeal the Seattle judge’s temporary restraining order, the White House used fairly muted language. Not so the president.

post_name: She Showed Up Yearly to Meet Immigration Agents. Now They’re Deporting Her.
post_message: Guadalupe García de Rayos was arrested Wednesday in Arizona — days after the definition of “criminal alien” was broadened — and told she would be deported to Mexico, a country she had not seen in 21 years.
post_description: Immigrants’ rights advocates say that a broadened definition of a term could easily apply to a majority of undocumented immigrants in the United States.

post_name: California Farmers Backed Trump, but Now Fear Losing Field Workers
post_message: "If you only have legal labor, certain parts of this industry and this region will not exist," one farmer said.
post_description: A Republican stronghold in the Central Valley thought a promise to crack down on illegal immigrants was just talk. Now they’re alarmed that it isn’t.

post_name: Crowdfunding Helps Rescue Refugees Upended by Travel Ban
post_message: "I believe without this I would never make it," said Hanan Isweiri, who feared not being able to return to her family in Colorado, following President Donald J. Trump's travel ban.
post_description: Fund-raising sites have let friends, neighbors and total strangers cover the expenses hanging over immigrants left in limbo by President Trump’s travel ban.

post_name: Day Without Immigrants to Hit Washington in the Stomach
post_message:
Some of Washington's best-known restaurants will close their doors today in solidarity with a national campaign to draw attention to the power and plight of immigrants.

Are you staying home for a "Day Without Immigrants" or have you noticed that a local business is closed or is short-staffed because of it? We'd like to know what's happening in your neighborhood. Please email callout@nytimes.com.
post_description: Restaurants in the capital are backing a campaign that asks foreign-born people not to work or shop in a demonstration of their economic importance.

post_name: Fake News, Fake Ukrainians: How Russians Tilted a Dutch Vote
post_message: Russians posing as Ukrainian immigrants in the Netherlands voted last April to reject a trade agreement between the EU and Ukraine.
post_description: With Europe facing critical elections, fears of Russian meddling are high. Many officials say the first test comes in March in the Netherlands.

post_name: Talk of Terror Listing for Muslim Brotherhood Alarms Some Arab Allies
post_message: In Morocco, it would tip a delicate political balance. In Jordan, it could prevent U.S. diplomats from meeting with opposition leaders.
post_description: One problem with any potential blanket designation of the Muslim Brotherhood is that the group takes different forms in different countries.

post_name: The Road, or Flight, From Detention to Deportation
post_message: For undocumented immigrants, the path between detention and deportation is sometimes long and usually twisted.
post_description: Any undocumented immigrant convicted of a crime or believed to have committed “acts that constitute a chargeable criminal offense” — essentially, anyone who is suspected of a crime, but has not yet been charged — is now at the top of the list.

post_name: New Trump Deportation Rules Allow Far More Expulsions
post_message: Breaking News: The Trump administration's new immigration policy greatly expands the categories of people subject to deportation.
post_description: The rules authorize expelling undocumented immigrants who have committed even minor offenses. And they make it easier to deport people immediately.

post_name: Trying to Stanch Trinidad’s Flow of Young Recruits to ISIS
post_message: A disproportionately large number of young ISIS fighters heads to Syria from Trinidad and Tobago.
post_description: Officials in Trinidad and Tobago are scrambling to close a pipeline that has sent a steady stream of Muslims to Syria to take up arms for the Islamic State.

post_name: Clashes in Stockholm Suburb Draw Attention to Trump’s Remarks
post_message: Residents in a Stockholm suburb predominantly inhabited by immigrants clashed with officers, 2 days after President Donald J. Trump criticized Sweden’s migration policies.
post_description: The episode between the police and residents came two days after President Trump made provocative claims about migration and crime in Sweden.

post_name: Danes Fighting for ISIS Were Paid Welfare Benefits, Government Says
post_message: The Danish government has been inadvertently paying benefits to citizens fighting for ISIS.
post_description: Denmark said a number of citizens receiving government pensions had traveled to Syria to take up arms for ISIS, as anti-immigration sentiment grew.

post_name: ‘The Daily’: Unambiguous Enforcement for an Unambiguous Law
post_message: Are 11 million people suddenly facing deportation?
post_description: What we know and don’t know about the Trump administration’s new plan for undocumented immigrants.

post_name: ‘The Daily’: Carlos’s Secret
post_message: What happened when federal agents showed up in a small town that had overwhelmingly voted for President Donald J. Trump.
post_description: The case that has shaken the whole town’s beliefs about politics, identity and immigration.

post_name: He’s a Local Pillar in a Trump Town. Now He Could Be Deported.
post_message: "In the case of Carlos, I think he may have done more for the people here than this place has ever given him. I think it’s absolutely terrible that he could be taken away."
post_description: Residents have only good things to say about Juan Carlos Hernandez Pacheco, but his arrest by immigration agents has left his Illinois town in a muddle.

post_name: Former President George W. Bush Levels Tacit Criticism at Trump
post_message: George W. Bush: “We need the media to hold people like me to account. I mean, power can be very addictive and it can be corrosive and it’s important for the media to call to account people who abuse their power, whether it be here or elsewhere.”
post_description: The former president took issue with the current president’s approach to immigration and the news media, and said that “we all need answers” on any potential ties to Russia.

post_name: Muslims Give Money to Jewish Institutions That Are Attacked
post_message: 2 attacks on Jewish cemeteries resulted in an outpouring of more than $136,000 in donations from thousands of Muslims and others.
post_description: Muslim activists have raised more than $136,000 in donations after vandalism in Jewish cemeteries and bomb threats at community centers and day schools.

post_name: ‘The Daily’: It Started at a Dinner Party
post_message: A look at the relationship between Stephen Bannon and Jeff Sessions.
post_description: What an event held years before Donald Trump announced his run for president tells us about the origins of his sweeping immigration plans.

post_name: Department of Justification
post_message: Stephen Bannon and Jeff Sessions have long shared a vision for remaking America. Now the nation's top law-enforcement agency can serve as a tool for enacting it.
post_description: Sessions said the 1924 immigration quota system, which barred most Asians and capped the entry of Italians, Jews, Africans and Middle Easterners, ‘was good for America.’

post_name: Migrants Confront Judgment Day Over Old Deportation Orders
post_message: "I feel hopeless," Juan said, who fled Colombia 6 years ago. "My wife is here, my son is here, they are my world. I have nowhere else to run to. I don't know what to do."
post_description: Unauthorized immigrants who have stayed in the United States after being ordered deported have emerged as an easy target of the Trump administration’s aims.

post_name: President Trump’s Island Mentality
post_message:
From The New York Times Opinion Section:

President Donald J. Trump's "instinct to wall off the world exacts its greatest human toll on America’s immigrants."
post_description: The repeated emphasis on “America First” worries allies, threatens global trade and hurts immigrants.

post_name: Trump Expected to Issue New Travel Ban Excluding Iraq on Monday
post_message: The new order would temporarily stop all refugee admissions to the United States, said a senior administration official.
post_description: The new order, reworked to try to withstand legal scrutiny, would retain temporary travel restrictions on six other predominantly Muslim countries and on all refugees.

post_name: Here’s the Reality About Illegal Immigrants in the United States
post_message: Many of the unauthorized are not Mexican; almost a quarter are not even Hispanic.

post_name: George Soros: When Hate Surges

post_name: Irish Premier Uses St. Patrick’s Day Ritual to Lecture Trump on Immigration
post_message: President Donald J. Trump found himself in a roomful of green-clad lawmakers being lectured about the virtues of America’s immigrant legacy and the contributions that immigrants had made to the country.
post_description: Prime Minister Enda Kenny called on the president to “remove a burden” from the estimated 50,000 Irish living in the United States illegally.

post_name: Amid ‘Trump Effect’ Fear, 40% of Colleges See Dip in Foreign Applicants
post_message: The biggest decline is in applications from the Middle East.
post_description: College officials wondered if there would be a price to pay for the president’s travel ban and the anti-Muslim rhetoric. Now the first numbers are in.

post_name: ‘The Daily’: Mike Pence’s Immigrant Roots

post_description: As the White House fights to protect the travel ban, we talk with Sheryl Gay Stolberg about the immigration story of our vice president.

post_name: Green Beer and Rank Hypocrisy
post_message: From The New York Times Opinion Section: "Does green beer taste better laced with hypocrisy? We may be about to find out, for this year’s St. Patrick's Day jamboree at the White House will be a breathtaking celebration of double standards."
post_description: Irish-Americans who remember what it is to be a scorned immigrant won’t be taken in by the Know Nothings in the White House.

post_name: President Trump’s Reckless Shame Game

post_description: Forcing local authorities to help round up unauthorized immigrants is wrong on both practical and constitutional grounds.

post_message: “I’ve always voted for him, but I think this was way out of line,” said Bill Kooi, a retired farmer, of Steve King's anti-immigrant tirade.

post_name: Iran to take 'reciprocal measures' after Trump's immigration order
post_message:
Iran is among seven countries whose nationals are barred from entering the United States for 90 days under Donald J. Trump's order, signed Friday.

Clarification: An earlier version of this article suggested that Americans would be banned from entering Iran. The Foreign Ministry statement says Iran has not yet decided on specific actions, but that it would consider legal, political and retaliatory measures against President Trump's executive order.
post_description: Iran is carefully studying US President Donald Trump's executive order limiting immigration from seven Muslim-majority countries and will take legal, political and reciprocal measures accordingly, Iran's Foreign Affairs Ministry announced Saturday.

post_name: Newest illegal immigrants face more scrutiny than many criminals - The Boston Globe

Federal officials have proposed expanding the program’s daily capacity to 53,000 next year.

post_name: Oslo college admits jailed mass killer - The Boston Globe
post_message: Convicted mass killer Anders Behring Breivik has been admitted to the University of Oslo’s political science program.

post_name: US-Cuba ties raise fear of deportation - The Boston Globe

post_name: Tenn. gunman had been depressed, family says - The Boston Globe

Authorities and friends have said they saw no evidence that Abdulazeez was a Muslim radical, and the spokesman said the man’s relatives didn’t, either.

post_name: GOP candidates too slow to denounce Donald Trump - The Boston Globe

Update: Aisling Brady McCarthy departed Boston's Logan airport for her native Ireland on Tuesday night.

post_name: Boston’s last tenement survives as an island awash in modern city - The Boston Globe
post_message: It is an entirely unremarkable building, except that 42 Lomasney Way is utterly amazing, a vestige of another Boston, a witness to history, a solitary survivor.
post_description: Once it was part of an unbroken chain, a row of 30 brick walk-ups along the east side of Lowell Street from Causeway to Minot, a matching row behind it, another across the street. There were hundreds like it back then, crammed into the immigrant neighborhood known as Boston’s West End.

post_message: France is a country balancing a law requiring a strict separation of church and state with the religious demands of its Muslim population.

post_name: Mayor Walsh stands with Hub’s Muslims - The Boston Globe

post_name: Charlie Baker slams Donald Trump Muslim plan - The Boston Globe
post_message: Here's what Charlie Baker had to say about Donald J. Trump's proposal banning Muslims from entering the US:  “I just sat here and celebrated the miracle of Hanukkah, which is about religious freedom. And the fight of the people of Jerusalem to ward off a bully who was trying to take away their right to peacefully practice their faith. I’m standing in a State House that’s less than a mile from the Warren Tavern, which is where the patriots of this nation began their initial conversations about how to secure their freedom out from under the British crown. And I’m standing in the State House, which is probably the most significant symbol in this city of the original fight for freedom, which goes all the way back to why people came here in the first place, which was to have a chance to practice their faith and their religion. And I can’t believe that I’m reading this, which is basically directly in contrast and in conflict with most of the most important values that people in this country hold most dear. Among them, the right and the ability to practice your religion peacefully. Yeah, I think this is a really bad idea.”
post_description: “I think that’s ridiculous and I would never support a policy like that,” Governor Charlie Baker said of Donald Trump’s proposal to temporarily stop Muslims from coming into the country.

Trump's comments: “Donald Trump is unhinged.” “His ‘policy’ proposals are not serious.” “It’s unrealistic . . . it’s inappropriate . . . it doesn’t make any sense.” “This is the kind of thing that people say when they have no experience and don’t know what they’re talking about.”

post_name: Rubio, Christie, and Bush fight for scraps - The Boston Globe
post_message: The three establishment candidates have adopted a strategy of ignoring the front-runners and beating up each other. | Via Boston Globe Opinion
post_description:
The two leading candidates for the Republican nomination, Ted Cruz and Donald Trump, are, combined, winning just under 60 percent of the GOP vote, but neither is electable in a general election.

According to the latest Gallup poll, Trump has a net favorability of negative 70 among Democrats and negative 27 among independents. Cruz’s ratings are the second worst; negative 37 among Democrats and minus 3 with independents.


Faced with such a dilemma, the most effective way to confront it would be to find a potential third nominee, one who is not a bombastic demagogue or a uniquely unlikable figure and would have a chance of winning non-Republican votes. Unfortunately, the pickings are slim. There’s Marco Rubio (11 percent in national polls), Jeb Bush (5 percent), and Chris Christie (3.5 percent). None of these three are great candidates. In fact, after Trump, Bush and Christie have the highest unfavorable ratings, with all voters, of any of the Republican candidates.

But they are all less likely to lead the GOP off the cliff toward an electoral shellacking.

So why then are the three so-called establishment candidates taking turns beating each other up? The super PAC for Jeb Bush, who knows a bit about watching his support go over a cliff, has taken the lead. This week it went after Rubio for flip-flopping on immigration (even though the two men largely agree on the issue); and the next day it ran another ad mocking him for his high-heeled boots.

Chris Christie has joined in as well, attacking Rubio for his electability and saying that Hillary Clinton would “cut his heart out” in a presidential debate. But, in fairness to Christie, Rubio started the fight. His super PAC ran an ad criticizing Christie’s record in New Jersey and Rubio joined in the fray by saying that Christie “has a very liberal record for a Republican.”

Rubio, however, wasn’t the only one attacking Christie. Bush’s super PAC sent out mailers in Iowa that criticized the New Jersey governor over the fact that his state’s credit rating has been downgraded “a record nine times” and for embracing “a massive expansion of Obamacare.”


Christie, who is not the type to let any insult go unanswered, struck back, claiming that Bush isn’t prepared for the White House, even though Bush served longer as governor than Christie.

This back-and-forth was on full display Thursday night at the GOP debate, with the only change being Rubio’s willingness to aggressively go after Ted Cruz. He hit the Texas senator for supporting a value-added tax, a charge Cruz denied. Cruz attacked Rubio over immigration; Rubio hit back. He attacked Christie for his support of Planned Parenthood, the Common Core, and gun control; Christie accused Rubio of being a do-nothing Senator. Rubio is today running a new ad that calls Jeb Bush, “desperate.” At least for his part, Bush aimed his barbs at Trump, but few others did.

Rubio, Christie, and Bush have all seemingly made the decision that the only way they can win is by knocking out the other two and then presenting themselves as the sane alternative to the front-runners. To say that is a long-shot strategy is putting it mildly. First of all, pitched political combat between Rubio, Christie, and Bush may weaken two of them more than the other — but it will certainly hurt all three. They will basically be previewing for voters the political attacks that Trump or Cruz will deploy against them if they emerge from the pack.

Second, this strategy is largely conceding Iowa and New Hampshire to Trump and Cruz. At best, the three men are fighting it out to finish second in New Hampshire or third in Iowa.

But what if Rubio gets third place in the Hawkeye State and Christie second in the Granite State? They will keep fighting it out and might even be joined by Bush, who could stay in the race until the Florida primary. This will only help Trump and Cruz.

Moreover, Bush, Christie, and Rubio are unlikely to do well in South Carolina (the next major primary state), and while Rubio might have an outside chance in Nevada, the next caucus state, by that point it won’t matter, especially if Trump wins Iowa, New Hampshire, and South Carolina (not a far-fetched possibility). As the campaign turns to the South, Trump and Cruz will be favored again, which makes even a late Rubio win in Nevada possibly irrelevant.

In short, the three establishment candidates have adopted a strategy of ignoring the front-runners and beating up each other, which can only serve to benefit the front-runners and hurt themselves.

It’s perhaps understandable why they are doing this: Getting in fights with Trump, for example, has not worked out well for any Republican this cycle. But what’s really needed is for the Republican establishment to coalesce around one candidate. That this hasn’t happened to date — and likely won’t in the next three weeks — is a good reminder as to how feckless and incapacitated the GOP establishment has become. To put it mildly, the GOP’s dilemma is likely only going to get worse.

Michael A. Cohen’s column appears regularly in the Globe. Follow him on Twitter @speechboy71.

post_name: Activist L.A. priest follows religion of acceptance
post_message:
Father Richard Estrada became a Catholic priest in 1978, and his work since then has included founding L.A.'s first homeless shelter geared toward immigrant youth. Central to his spiritual outlook is the concept of la posada — the Spanish word for inn, or lodging. 

In recent years, he has struggled to square that ethic with elements of Catholic doctrine that he felt were unwelcoming. Last year, he joined the Episcopal Church, in part because it allows women, gays and lesbians to serve as priests and bishops.
post_description: "I should be retiring, not starting a new career," Estrada said, smiling as he puttered around the kitchen. "But I had to be true to myself. God is putting me places. He or She is in charge."

post_name: Attorney general pick Loretta Lynch shaped by work with Rwanda tribunal
post_message:
When attorney general nominee Loretta Lynch lost her political appointment as a U.S. attorney in 2001, she took an unusual career detour: working as a volunteer legal advisor to the International Criminal Tribunal in Rwanda. 

The experience — helping to train the lawyers tasked with prosecuting those responsible for the 1994 genocide — gave Lynch a global perspective that sets her apart from most who have held the top U.S. law enforcement job.
post_description: As a longtime federal prosecutor in Brooklyn, N.Y., Loretta Lynch confronted murderers, the Mafia and violent drug peddlers. She is probably best known for convicting two New York police officers in the 1997 broomstick sodomizing of Haitian immigrant Abner Louima.

post_name: Denial of parole for Mexican Mafia killer a relief to victim's family
post_message: Former Mexico Mafia leader Rene Enriquez's work with law enforcement earned him special treatment behind bars, The parole board found Enriquez, who is  serving a life  sentence for two murders,  suitable for release. But Gov. Jerry Brown reversed the boards decision, writing that Enriquez's contributions were outweighed by his violent history and the risk to society.
post_description: Rene Enriquez's eloquence on the subject of the Mexican Mafia prison gang has impressed many . He wrote two books on the topic, prosecutors used him as an expert witness in gang trials, and numerous law enforcement officials turned to him for training sessions and conferences.

post_name: Mexico fields unflattering comments from 'Birdman' director, others
post_message:

While Nieto ignored the slight, many Mexico newspapers have highlighted the remarks and social media has been aflame with reaction.
post_description: From the Oscars in Hollywood, to the pope in Rome, Mexico is receiving some rather unflattering attention.

post_name: Vatican apologizes to Mexico over pope's comment on drug trafficking
post_message: The Vatican has issued a rare "mea culpa" for controversial comments the pope made in a private email that was published: “The pope did not mean to hurt the feelings of the Mexican people, nor did he intend to minimize the efforts of the Mexican government” in the fight against drug trafficking, papal spokesman Rev. Federico Lombardi told reporters in Rome.
post_description: In a private email to a friend, Francis had warned against the “Mexicanization” of their native Argentina, a reference to the dominance of drug-trafficking and violence.

post_name: Senate leaders reach deal to avoid Homeland Security shutdown
